issue.title: Size of pdf grows enourmously
issue.body:
I have requirement of creating a pdf from other pdf with specific pages alone

This is windows 10 . I am using python 3.7 and latest pymupdf version

The source pdf size is 51 MB .The output which i create from it is 700 Mb

cluster_page_numbers is a list which has all the page numbers to be present in the output

for cluster_page_number in cluster_page_numbers:
                    if cluster_page_number <= source_file_handle.pageCount:
                        cluster_file_handle.insertPDF(source_file_handle, from_page=cluster_page_number - 1,
                                                      to_page=cluster_page_number - 1)

Finally save cluster_file_handle

Please assist on this

comment.body:
> And again: if you are looking for an efficient way to remove a list of pages from a PDF and then save it under a new name, then the following should be a lot less troublesome:
> 
> ```python
> pagelist = [...] # list of pages to remove from the PDF
> for page in reversed(source_file_handle):  # iterate back to front!
>     if page.number not in pagelist:  # keep this page
>         continue
>     source_file_handle.deletePage(page.number)
> 
> source_file_handle.save("Big_bursted.pdf", garbage=4, deflate=True) # save under the new name
> # original file will remain untouched!
> ```
> 
> This ensures that the file will not become any bigger at least, and (probably) smaller instead. It is **_important_** to iterate back to front, because after each page delete, the numbers of subsequent pages will change.

@JorjMcKie I used this logic to delete few pages, but the file size is not decreasing. I need annotation of pages except deleted pages. Any idea on this, If I use garbage =4 the program will be so slow, It needs huge time to save even a single pdf page.

issue.title: Arabic Letters With Figo Font are Disjoined
issue.body:
After Following this issue **TextWriter.writeText : Arabic texts are saved in the document from left to right instead of right-left #897**
i was able to write Arabic but the letters are disjointed 

```
page.insert_textbox( bbox ,translated_text[::-1] ,fontsize= 10 ,fontname= "figo",align="r")
```

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/89604782/169288723-951cfcfd-4a82-4064-8e00-d4049530fc03.png)

 - Operating system: Working on google colab
 - Python version: Latest 
 - PyMuPDF version: !pip install PyMuPDF

Any ideas on what will make the letters joined as usual in Arabic. For Example i need  --> محتويات instead of م ح ت و ي ا ت

comment.body:
> @JorjMcKie any update on this?

Sorry, no news here.

issue.title: Cannot insert text with floating point fontsize/non-zero render mode
issue.body:
Hello,

I recently upgraded from PyMuPDF version 1.22.3 to version 1.23.5 and I can no longer insert text into pages using a floating point fontsize with a render_mode besides zero. All documentation suggests that floats should still be supported, and this approach worked in version 1.22.3 without issue. The issue goes away if I either use a render_mode of 0 or an integer fontsize.

## Describe the bug (mandatory)
PyMuPDF raises the following error when trying to call page.insert_text() with a floating point fontsize and a non-zero render_mode.

![image](https://github.com/pymupdf/PyMuPDF/assets/46684044/8ac77069-ddfa-48f3-ac99-029809d7efb8)

## To Reproduce (mandatory)
Please use attached script and sample PDF. I believe the same error will be raised for any input PDF though.
[sample.pdf](https://github.com/pymupdf/PyMuPDF/files/13181452/sample.pdf)

[script.py.txt](https://github.com/pymupdf/PyMuPDF/files/13181454/script.py.txt)


## Expected behavior (optional)
Text is inserted without error.

## Your configuration (mandatory)
 - Ubuntu 22.04
 - Python 3.10.6
 - PyMuPDF versions 1.22.3 and 1.23.5, both installed with pip

comment.body: If brackets are omitted, the formatting replacement character "%" binds stronger than the multiplication. If then the fontsize is an integer no error is detected, but the string is replicated a respective number of times.

As well as line 3918. Both in `utils.py`

issue.title: For some documents, many words get lumped together by get_text()
issue.body:
## Describe the bug 
I'm trying to *extract text from PDF documents*, to isolate individual words and create an indexing system. 

For most PDF files, pymupdf (version 1.23.5) does a fine job... but for some files (such as the one enclosed, "Gravity.pdf"), *a lot of words emerge glued together.*

## To Reproduce 
**The file in question (but NOT the only one!) is** : [Gravity.pdf](https://github.com/pymupdf/PyMuPDF/files/13064843/Gravity.pdf)

```
pip install pymupdf
import fitz
print(fitz.__doc__)    # Says  "PyMuPDF 1.23.5: Python bindings for the MuPDF 1.23.4 library"
pdf_name = "Gravity.pdf"
doc = fitz.open(pdf_name)
doc.metadata    # Shows:   'format': 'PDF 1.6'
page = doc.load_page(11)
page.get_text(flags=fitz.TEXT_PRESERVE_WHITESPACE | fitz.TEXT_MEDIABOX_CLIP | fitz.TEXT_DEHYPHENATE)
```

## Output
It contains several words fused together, such as in this portion
``` and,\nsureenough,bothfellwiththesameaccelerationandreachedthe\nMoon’s surface together.2```

## Screenshots
Full text of the parse:
![error](https://github.com/pymupdf/PyMuPDF/assets/41893046/a15966dc-31c4-4ea2-891c-4e8d5cf765d0)

This is how it looks in the PDF:
![source](https://github.com/pymupdf/PyMuPDF/assets/41893046/5b0b63d3-cf65-4349-9e02-06bfc916611c)


## Your configuration
 - I've tried it both on *my local computer* AND on *Google Colab.*  The problem is the same!

```print(sys.version, "\n", sys.platform, "\n", fitz.__doc__)``` 
on Colab gives:
```
PyMuPDF 1.23.5: Python bindings for the MuPDF 1.23.4 library.
Version date: 2023-10-11 00:00:01.
Built for Python 3.10 on linux (64-bit).
```

On my local computer, it gives:
```
 win32 
 
PyMuPDF 1.23.5: Python bindings for the MuPDF 1.23.4 library.
Version date: 2023-10-11 00:00:01.
Built for Python 3.8 on win32 (64-bit).
```

- PyMuPDF version, installation method (**wheel** or **generated** from source).

On Colab, I issue `!pip install pymupdf` , and it says:

```
Collecting pymupdf
  Downloading PyMuPDF-1.23.5-cp310-none-manylinux2014_x86_64.whl (4.3 MB)
     ━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━ 4.3/4.3 MB 12.5 MB/s eta 0:00:00
Collecting PyMuPDFb==1.23.5 (from pymupdf)
  Downloading PyMuPDFb-1.23.5-py3-none-manylinux2014_x86_64.manylinux_2_17_x86_64.whl (30.6 MB)
     ━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━ 30.6/30.6 MB 43.3 MB/s eta 0:00:00
Installing collected packages: PyMuPDFb, pymupdf
Successfully installed PyMuPDFb-1.23.5 pymupdf-1.23.5
```

On my local computer, I let PyCharm deal with it.  (I think it does a `pip install`)


## Additional context
Words fused together occur A LOT when parsing the attached PDF.

I suspect you'll say that this file is malformed. Maybe it is... but another software library, `pypdf` , parses it just fine.

I have noticed that the lost spaces are far more prevalent in extractions by `pypdf`, compared to PyMuPDF - BUT for some files (such as the one I'm reporting here) it's the opposite, and `pypdf` does far better.

Empirically, I've noticed an *intriguing complementary between `pypdf` and `PyMuPDF`* : for files where one messes up badly, the other one does well - and vice versa. Maybe a different threshold of how to detect blank spaces in sentences?  Maybe some insight to gain from this??

Thanks!

comment.body:
@BrainAnnex - thank you very much for your feedback!
We are glad you find PyMuPDF useful.

>  maybe some complementary aspect in their word-detection algorithms??)

No, this is as simple as a lower threshold value for inter-character distances. In the case of your example, word separation will work congruently to the reader's perception if a distance larger than 25% of the current to the next character is taken as that threshold. This means, that the following code snippet will produce a satisfactory output:
```python
import fitz

doc = fitz.open("Gravity.pdf")
page = doc[11]
space_count = 0
space_w = 0
for b in page.get_text("rawdict", flags=fitz.TEXTFLAGS_TEXT, sort=True)["blocks"]:
    for l in b["lines"]:
        text = ""
        chars = []
        for s in l["spans"]:
            chars.extend(s["chars"])
        char_count = len(chars)
        if char_count == 1:
            print(chars[0]["c"])
            continue
        for i in range(1, char_count):
            c0 = chars[i - 1]
            r0 = fitz.Rect(c0["bbox"])
            c1 = chars[i]
            r1 = fitz.Rect(c1["bbox"])
            text += c0["c"]
            if (c0["c"] != " " and c1["c"] != " "
                and r1.x0 - r0.x1 >= r0.width * 0.25):
                # distance to next char if both aren't space
                text += " "
            if c1["c"] == " ":
                space_count += 1
                space_w += r1.width
        print(text + c1["c"])
```

issue.body:
## Describe the bug

doc = fitz.open(pdf_name)
doc.metadata    # Shows:   'format': 'PDF 1.6'
page = doc.load_page(11)
page.get_text(flags=fitz.TEXT_PRESERVE_WHITESPACE | fitz.TEXT_MEDIABOX_CLIP | fitz.TEXT_DEHYPHENATE)

## Output
It contains several words fused together, such as in this portion
``` and,\nsureenough,bothfellwiththesameaccelerationandreachedthe\nMoon’s surface together.2```

## Screenshots

![error](https://github.com/pymupdf/PyMuPDF/assets/41893046/a15966dc-31c4-4ea2-891c-4e8d5cf765d0)

This is how it looks in the PDF:
![source](https://github.com/pymupdf/PyMuPDF/assets/41893046/5b0b63d3-cf65-4349-9e02-06bfc916611c)


## Your configuration

```print(sys.version, "\n", sys.platform, "\n", fitz.__doc__)``` 
on Colab gives:

PyMuPDF 1.23.5: Python bindings for the MuPDF 1.23.4 library.

 win32

Version date: 2023-10-11 00:00:01.
Built for Python 3.8 on win32 (64-bit).
```

- PyMuPDF version, installation method (**wheel** or **generated** from source).

On Colab, I issue `!pip install pymupdf` , and it says:

```
Collecting pymupdf
  Downloading PyMuPDF-1.23.5-cp310-none-manylinux2014_x86_64.whl (4.3 MB)
     ━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━ 4.3/4.3 MB 12.5 MB/s eta 0:00:00
Collecting PyMuPDFb==1.23.5 (from pymupdf)
  Downloading PyMuPDFb-1.23.5-py3-none-manylinux2014_x86_64.manylinux_2_17_x86_64.whl (30.6 MB)

Installing collected packages: PyMuPDFb, pymupdf
Successfully installed PyMuPDFb-1.23.5 pymupdf-1.23.5
```

On my local computer, I let PyCharm deal with it.  (I think it does a `pip install`)


## Additional context

I suspect you'll say that this file is malformed. Maybe it is... but another software library, `pypdf` , parses it just fine.

I have noticed that the lost spaces are far more prevalent in extractions by `pypdf`, compared to PyMuPDF - BUT for some files (such as the one I'm reporting here) it's the opposite, and `pypdf` does far better.

Empirically, I've noticed an *intriguing complementary between `pypdf` and `PyMuPDF`* : for files where one messes up badly, the other one does well - and vice versa. Maybe a different threshold of how to detect blank spaces in sentences?  Maybe some insight to gain from this??

Thanks!

comment.body:
Thanks @JorjMcKie !   I'm expanding the open-source project [BrainAnnex.org](https://BrainAnnex.org) to also provide a full-text indexing/search feature for documents (incl. PDF) managed by a "Knowledge and multimedia content management system" that employs the power of graph databases...  I elaborate in [this article](https://julianspolymathexplorations.blogspot.com/2023/08/full-text-search-neo4j-indexing.html).

I happen to have a substantial number of PDF books, scientific papers and other documents at my disposal... and I'm using some of them to test the system.  

The extraction of individual words is the key element for this process.

Empirically, I found that `PyMuPDF` is vastly better than `pdfplumber` , and typically substantially better than `pypdf` - though, as I mentioned, there is a smallish but non-trivial number of cases where `PyMuPDF` errs a lot (and, interestingly `pypdf` does well in those cases... maybe some complementary aspect in their word-detection algorithms??)

I'm definitely impressed by your efforts with `PyMuPDF` , and the efforts of the `MuPDF` team!

I will experiment with the "rawdict" algorithm that you proposed - thanks! - and will report on the results.  I understand that word detection in PDF's is something of an art form!

commits.message:
src/__init__.py: make_escape(): ensure we escape 0xfffd replacements for orphaned surrogate characters.

Only effects use with mupdf <= 1.23.4 - later mupdf never give us orphaned
surrogates.

src/extra.i: JM_append_rune(): change handling of 128..255 to match __init__.py.

Not sure it's safe to have raw 128..255 characters in generated data. (However
classic implementation does have them.)

tests/test_general.py: test_2553(): cope with mupdf 1.23.4 and earlier.

mupdf-1.23.4 gives us orphaned surrogate characters, so we need to change
whether we expect 0xFFFD replacements depending on the mupdf version.

Also print out the various lists we are testing, useful for debugging.

issue.title: Unexpected table cell contents when opening multiple PDFs
issue.body:
_**Please provide all mandatory information!**_

First of all, thank you very much for implementing the find_tables feature, it works great and is incredibly useful for a lot of us I think!

## Describe the bug (mandatory)
When opening more than one PDF document at a time, the contents returned by <Table>.extract() is unexpected.

## To Reproduce (mandatory)

```
import fitz

doc = fitz.open("national-capitals.pdf")

tables = []
for page in doc:  # iterate over the pages
    tabs = page.find_tables()  # locate tables on page
    if len(tabs.tables) == []:  # no tables found?
        break  # stop
    tab = tabs[0]  # assume fragment to be 1st table
    tables.append(tab)  # append this DataFrame

# Everything as expected until here

doc_2 = fitz.open("input1.pdf")
tables_2 = []
for page in doc_2:  # iterate over the pages
    tabs = page.find_tables()  # locate tables on page
    if len(tabs.tables) == []:  # no tables found?
        break  # stop
    tab = tabs[0]  # assume fragment to be 1st table
    tables_2.append(tab)  # append this DataFrame

# This returns text from the input1.pdf, not national-capitals.pdf as intended
df = pd.concat([tab.to_pandas() for tab in tables])
```

## Expected behavior (optional)
I expect the df from the code above to contain the contents of the tables held by the national-capitals.pdf document.

## Your configuration (mandatory)
3.9.13 (v3.9.13:6de2ca5339, May 17 2022, 11:37:23) 
[Clang 13.0.0 (clang-1300.0.29.30)] 
 darwin 
 
PyMuPDF 1.23.5: Python bindings for the MuPDF 1.23.4 library.
Version date: 2023-10-11 00:00:01.
Built for Python 3.9 on darwin (64-bit).

## Additional context (optional)
I think this is due to the namespace management in the table functions.

comment.body:
The background of your problem is that tables contain references to the table finder object and the page.
So storing a table somewhere else e.g. in an array, beyond the lifetime of the owning table finder and page objects **_must_** **_necessarily_** lead to errors.

The only problem you have been facing is that no exception has been raised as would have been appropriate.

If you want to keep table content after its parent table finder and page are dead, this can only be done in a format without dependencies from original page and table finders - most suitable pandas DataFrame as shown in my snippet.

issue.title: Layers got deleted Automatically on saving PDF page.
issue.body:
@JorjMcKie I am creating new pdf page based on page number , While creating new pdf page all annotation attribute are correct except Layer.Layers got automatically removed while saving pdf page. This is my code.

output_pdf_with_color = fitz.open(filetype = "pdf")
input_pdf_page = fitz.open(input_src_path,filetype = "pdf")
  ##Page Number to be prepared,response data
  for page_no in pdf_markup_rslt[subsystem_key]['Page No']:
      page_no_in_str = page_no_in_str + ' Pages ' + str(page_no)
      output_pdf_with_color.insert_pdf(input_pdf_page,from_page = page_no-1, to_page = page_no-1, links=1, annots=1)


      pdf_with_color = os.path.join(subsystem_dir, '{}_final.pdf'.format(subsystem_key))
      output_pdf_with_color.save(pdf_with_color)`

Could you please let me know How to fix it ?

![image](https://github.com/pymupdf/PyMuPDF/assets/43229248/b716c0da-f00e-441b-b7f8-a8b66d208aab)


Original file contains layers.

Thank you

comment.body:
For the time being, this is not a bug, but a question.
Transferring to "Discussions".

issue.title: For some documents, many words get lumped together by get_text()
issue.body:
## Describe the bug 
I'm trying to *extract text from PDF documents*, to isolate individual words and create an indexing system. 

For most PDF files, pymupdf (version 1.23.5) does a fine job... but for some files (such as the one enclosed, "Gravity.pdf"), *a lot of words emerge glued together.*

## To Reproduce 
**The file in question (but NOT the only one!) is** : [Gravity.pdf](https://github.com/pymupdf/PyMuPDF/files/13064843/Gravity.pdf)

```
pip install pymupdf
import fitz
print(fitz.__doc__)    # Says  "PyMuPDF 1.23.5: Python bindings for the MuPDF 1.23.4 library"
pdf_name = "Gravity.pdf"
doc = fitz.open(pdf_name)
doc.metadata    # Shows:   'format': 'PDF 1.6'
page = doc.load_page(11)
page.get_text(flags=fitz.TEXT_PRESERVE_WHITESPACE | fitz.TEXT_MEDIABOX_CLIP | fitz.TEXT_DEHYPHENATE)
```

## Output
It contains several words fused together, such as in this portion
``` and,\nsureenough,bothfellwiththesameaccelerationandreachedthe\nMoon’s surface together.2```

## Screenshots
Full text of the parse:
![error](https://github.com/pymupdf/PyMuPDF/assets/41893046/a15966dc-31c4-4ea2-891c-4e8d5cf765d0)

This is how it looks in the PDF:
![source](https://github.com/pymupdf/PyMuPDF/assets/41893046/5b0b63d3-cf65-4349-9e02-06bfc916611c)


## Your configuration
 - I've tried it both on *my local computer* AND on *Google Colab.*  The problem is the same!

```print(sys.version, "\n", sys.platform, "\n", fitz.__doc__)``` 
on Colab gives:
```
PyMuPDF 1.23.5: Python bindings for the MuPDF 1.23.4 library.
Version date: 2023-10-11 00:00:01.
Built for Python 3.10 on linux (64-bit).
```

On my local computer, it gives:
```
 win32 
 
PyMuPDF 1.23.5: Python bindings for the MuPDF 1.23.4 library.
Version date: 2023-10-11 00:00:01.
Built for Python 3.8 on win32 (64-bit).
```

- PyMuPDF version, installation method (**wheel** or **generated** from source).

On Colab, I issue `!pip install pymupdf` , and it says:

```
Collecting pymupdf
  Downloading PyMuPDF-1.23.5-cp310-none-manylinux2014_x86_64.whl (4.3 MB)
     ━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━ 4.3/4.3 MB 12.5 MB/s eta 0:00:00
Collecting PyMuPDFb==1.23.5 (from pymupdf)
  Downloading PyMuPDFb-1.23.5-py3-none-manylinux2014_x86_64.manylinux_2_17_x86_64.whl (30.6 MB)
     ━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━ 30.6/30.6 MB 43.3 MB/s eta 0:00:00
Installing collected packages: PyMuPDFb, pymupdf
Successfully installed PyMuPDFb-1.23.5 pymupdf-1.23.5
```

On my local computer, I let PyCharm deal with it.  (I think it does a `pip install`)


## Additional context
Words fused together occur A LOT when parsing the attached PDF.

I suspect you'll say that this file is malformed. Maybe it is... but another software library, `pypdf` , parses it just fine.

I have noticed that the lost spaces are far more prevalent in extractions by `pypdf`, compared to PyMuPDF - BUT for some files (such as the one I'm reporting here) it's the opposite, and `pypdf` does far better.

Empirically, I've noticed an *intriguing complementary between `pypdf` and `PyMuPDF`* : for files where one messes up badly, the other one does well - and vice versa. Maybe a different threshold of how to detect blank spaces in sentences?  Maybe some insight to gain from this??

Thanks!

comment.body:
For consideration, here is test script, that fiddles together an alternative plain text output based on a per-character extraction.
This time, we trigger a word break, whenever the inter-character distance exceeds 1.5. The last line print the number of spaces as detected, respectively generated (by MuPDF) and the average width of these "natural" spaces:
```python
import fitz

doc = fitz.open("Gravity.pdf")
page = doc[11]
space_count = 0
space_w = 0
for b in page.get_text("rawdict", flags=fitz.TEXTFLAGS_TEXT, sort=True)["blocks"]:
    for l in b["lines"]:
        text = ""
        chars = []
        for s in l["spans"]:
            chars.extend(s["chars"])
        char_count = len(chars)
        if char_count == 1:
            print(chars[0]["c"])
            continue
        for i in range(1, char_count):
            c0 = chars[i - 1]
            r0 = fitz.Rect(c0["bbox"])
            c1 = chars[i]
            r1 = fitz.Rect(c1["bbox"])
            text += c0["c"]
            if r1.x0 - r0.x1 >= 1.5:
                text += " "
            if c1["c"] == " ":
                space_count += 1
                space_w += r1.width
        print(text + c1["c"])
print()
print(f"space count {space_count}, avg width = {space_w/space_count}")
```
The output is as the reaer of the page would expect:
```
Can You Feel the Force?
3
front of a video camera (Figure 0.1).1 In the absence of any atmo-
sphere, the hammer and feather fell without any air resistance;
the only force acting upon them was the Moon’s gravity and,
sure enough, both fell with the same acceleration and reached the
Moon’s surface together.2
What would it feel like to fall towards the Moon’s surface along
with the feather and the hammer? We would fall at the same rate
as these other objects and hit the ground alongside both. Even
more importantly, all the parts of our body would be acceler-
ated in exactly the same way. Our head would fall with the same
acceleration as our kneecaps. Our feet would fall with the same
acceleration as our boots, consequently we would not feel any-
thing at all—we would be weightless. There is nothing special
about gravity on the Moon. What is special about the Moon is that
it is airless and, as there is no air resistance, the only force acting
on us is gravity.
Figure 0.1 Apollo 15 astronaut David Scott is standing on the Moon’s
surface holding a hammer in his right hand and a feather in his left.

space count 172, avg width = 2.584325213764989
```

issue.title: Segmentation Fault when inserting three (but not two) copies of the same source page into one destination page
issue.body:
## Describe the bug (mandatory)

When copying the same page three times into one destination page, a segmentation fault happens.

## To Reproduce (mandatory)

Download [dummy.pdf](https://github.com/pymupdf/PyMuPDF/files/12907100/dummy.pdf), and run this script:

~~~py
import fitz

dest = fitz.open()
destpage = dest.new_page(width=842, height=595)

a5 = fitz.Rect(0, 0, destpage.rect.width / 3, destpage.rect.height)
shiftright = fitz.Rect(destpage.rect.width/3, 0, destpage.rect.width/3, 0)

src = fitz.open("dummy.pdf")

destpage.show_pdf_page(a5, src, 0)
destpage.show_pdf_page(a5 + shiftright, src, 0)
destpage.show_pdf_page(a5 + shiftright + shiftright, src, 0)

dest.save("dummy-nup.pdf")
print("The end!")
~~~

## Expected behavior (optional)

The scripts runs without errors, and produces a file `dummy-nup.pdf` with three copies of the only page of `dummy.pdf` on its first page.

## Screenshots (optional)

~~~bash
(312) louis@oryx:~/projets/pdfautonup/src$ python nup.py
The end!
Segmentation fault
~~~

## Your configuration (mandatory)

 - Operating system, potentially version and bitness: Debian trixie.
 - Python version, bitness: Python 3.12.0 (installed from the [Debian repositories](https://packages.debian.org/trixie/python3.12))
 - PyMuPDF version, installation method (**wheel** or **generated** from source) :  1.23.5, installed from wheel (I guess?)

For example, the output of `print(sys.version, "\n", sys.platform, "\n", fitz.__doc__)` would be sufficient (for the first two bullets).

~~~bash
$ pip install pymupdf
Collecting pymupdf
  Obtaining dependency information for pymupdf from https://files.pythonhosted.org/packages/1c/9b/ad383fe1949b5925b903ff57bd915dd6e3479c8229f16942f22324e393d4/PyMuPDF-1.23.5-cp312-none-manylinux2014_x86_64.whl.metadata
  Using cached PyMuPDF-1.23.5-cp312-none-manylinux2014_x86_64.whl.metadata (3.4 kB)
Requirement already satisfied: PyMuPDFb==1.23.5 in /home/louis/.virtualenvs/312/lib/python3.12/site-packages (from pymupdf) (1.23.5)
Using cached PyMuPDF-1.23.5-cp312-none-manylinux2014_x86_64.whl (4.3 MB)
Installing collected packages: pymupdf
Successfully installed pymupdf-1.23.5
$ python -c 'import sys, fitz; print(sys.version, "\n", sys.platform, "\n", fitz.__doc__)'
3.12.0 (main, Oct  4 2023, 06:27:34) [GCC 13.2.0] 
 linux 
 
PyMuPDF 1.23.5: Python bindings for the MuPDF 1.23.4 library.
Version date: 2023-10-11 00:00:01.
Built for Python 3.12 on linux (64-bit).
~~~

## Additional context (optional)

A few (weird?) things:

- The script ends with a segmentation fault *at the end of it*: the `print()` called at the last line is executed: the segmentation fault happens *after it*.
- The segmentation fault disappears if the page is copied twice instead of thrice (if line 13 is removed).
- The script works: output file is generated as expected, in spite of the segmentation fault.
- The script works (without segmentation fault) with the very same pymupdf version and python3.11.
- The segmentation fault happens even if the destination file is not written (i.e. if line `dest.save(…)` is removed).
- `fitz.__doc__` reads: `PyMuPDF 1.23.5: Python bindings for the MuPDF 1.23.4 library.`: Could the version mismatch here explain the problem?

Thanks for your work!
Louis

comment.body:
We are going to lower the priority of resolving this, because the new alternative implementation of PyMuPDF does not have this problem.
Therefore, as an immediate solution, change the import statement in affected scripts to ìmport fitz_new as fitz`.

issue.title: After applying redactions with Page.add_redact_annot() some text disappears outside the redaction areas (in this example)

labels.name: not a bug
labels.description: not a bug / user error / unable to reproduce

issue.body:
## Describe the bug (mandatory)
For a simple example document, using `Page.add_redact_annot()` on words found with `Page.get_text("words")` appears to correctly mark the redactions. But, when the same redactions are applied, other text disappears outside of the redactions.

## To Reproduce 
Minimal code snippet:
```python
    import fitz
    def minimal(input_pdf_path: Path, output_pdf_path: Path, apply_redactions: bool = False):
        doc = fitz.open(input_pdf_path)
        for page in doc:
            words = page.get_text("words", delimiters=".,;:")
            for word in words:
                if "(" in word[4] and ")" in word[4]:
                    page.add_redact_annot(
                        word[:4],
                        fill=(0, 0, 0),
                        text="D.O.B.",
                        text_color=(1, 1, 1),
                        fontsize=12,
                        align=fitz.TEXT_ALIGN_CENTER,
                    )
            if apply_redactions:
                page.apply_redactions()
        doc.save(output_pdf_path)
        doc.close()

    minimal("source.pdf","unapplied.pdf", apply_redactions = False)
    minimal("source.pdf","applied.pdf", apply_redactions = True)
```
[source.pdf](https://github.com/pymupdf/PyMuPDF/files/13140626/source.pdf)

## Expected behavior (optional)
Only the text inside the marked redaction areas should be gone

## Screenshots (optional)

source.pdf looks like this:
![ClipboardImage](https://github.com/pymupdf/PyMuPDF/assets/77492177/f3d2e5d6-e078-45c4-a283-11f9298ee425)

unapplied.pdf looks like this (shows the intended redactions as expected):
![ClipboardImage (0001)](https://github.com/pymupdf/PyMuPDF/assets/77492177/03336e95-27b8-42d0-a1cb-e092bbee44fa)

applied.pdf looks like this (note some text outside the redaction areas, in lines above the redactions, is gone):
![ClipboardImage (0002)](https://github.com/pymupdf/PyMuPDF/assets/77492177/9473d9f5-98e3-4bc0-9e57-175550b5775d)

Same artifacts occur on lines below the redactions, though my example here doesn't show that.
## Your configuration (mandatory)
 - Microsoft Windows 10 Enterprise 10.0.19044 x64 
 - Python 3.11.3 (main, May  7 2023, 18:40:36) [MSC v.1929 64 bit (AMD64)]
 - pymupdf==1.23.5, pip install version (wheel)

## Additional context (optional)
Easily possible this is user error rather than a bug. 

Note the source.pdf file is provided to me from outside.

I am able to get close to the desired result by changing the parameters as follows, but it doesn't look quite right and seems hacky.

                page.add_redact_annot(
                    (word[0], word[1] + 3, word[2], word[3] - 2),
                    fill=(0, 0, 0),
                    text="D.O.B.",
                    text_color=(1, 1, 1),
                    fontsize=8,
                    align=fitz.TEXT_ALIGN_CENTER,
                )

This change yields:
![ClipboardImage (0003)](https://github.com/pymupdf/PyMuPDF/assets/77492177/ac8a4355-77ea-469d-803b-94f9bf461e43)

I am loving this library and I truly appreciate the work done on it. It makes my life so much easier.

issue.title: RuntimeError: exception stack overflow! when reading pages

labels.name: not a bug
labels.description: not a bug / user error / unable to reproduce

issue.body:
## Describtion of the bug
A stack overflow appear when I try to convert all the pages of the PDF to text.

```
File ".local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/fitz/utils.py", line 825, in get_text
    tp = page.get_textpage(clip=clip, flags=flags)
File ".local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/fitz/fitz.py", line 6017, in get_textpage
    textpage = self._get_textpage(clip, flags=flags, matrix=matrix)
File ".local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/fitz/fitz.py", line 6003, in _get_textpage
    val = _fitz.Page__get_textpage(self, clip, flags, matrix)
RuntimeError: exception stack overflow!
```

## To Reproduce

```
import io
import requests
import fitz

pdf_link = 'https://arxiv.org/pdf/2107.10846.pdf'
request = requests.get(pdf_link, timeout=20)
filestream = io.BytesIO(request.content)

with fitz.open(stream=filestream, filetype="pdf") as doc: 
    pages = [page.get_text() for page in doc]
```

## Configuration
 - Ubuntu 22.04 64 bits
 - Python 3.10.12 64bits
 - PyMuPDF 1.23.5, install from pip

## Additional context
Some other PDF files that raise the same RuntimeError
- https://arxiv.org/pdf/2109.14658.pdf
- https://arxiv.org/pdf/2109.13752.pdf

comment.body: Yeah, PDF viewers behave differently. I don't know which PDF plugin is being used by your Firefox - that even is not the same one on all platforms ...

issue.title: Unexpected table cell contents when opening multiple PDFs
issue.body:
_**Please provide all mandatory information!**_

First of all, thank you very much for implementing the find_tables feature, it works great and is incredibly useful for a lot of us I think!

## Describe the bug (mandatory)
When opening more than one PDF document at a time, the contents returned by <Table>.extract() is unexpected.

## To Reproduce (mandatory)

```
import fitz

doc = fitz.open("national-capitals.pdf")

tables = []
for page in doc:  # iterate over the pages
    tabs = page.find_tables()  # locate tables on page
    if len(tabs.tables) == []:  # no tables found?
        break  # stop
    tab = tabs[0]  # assume fragment to be 1st table
    tables.append(tab)  # append this DataFrame

# Everything as expected until here

doc_2 = fitz.open("input1.pdf")
tables_2 = []
for page in doc_2:  # iterate over the pages
    tabs = page.find_tables()  # locate tables on page
    if len(tabs.tables) == []:  # no tables found?
        break  # stop
    tab = tabs[0]  # assume fragment to be 1st table
    tables_2.append(tab)  # append this DataFrame

# This returns text from the input1.pdf, not national-capitals.pdf as intended
df = pd.concat([tab.to_pandas() for tab in tables])
```

## Expected behavior (optional)
I expect the df from the code above to contain the contents of the tables held by the national-capitals.pdf document.

## Your configuration (mandatory)
3.9.13 (v3.9.13:6de2ca5339, May 17 2022, 11:37:23) 
[Clang 13.0.0 (clang-1300.0.29.30)] 
 darwin 
 
PyMuPDF 1.23.5: Python bindings for the MuPDF 1.23.4 library.
Version date: 2023-10-11 00:00:01.
Built for Python 3.9 on darwin (64-bit).

## Additional context (optional)
I think this is due to the namespace management in the table functions.

comment.body:
You can correct your code like this:
```python
tables = []
for page in doc:  # iterate over the pages
    if page.number > 2:
        break
    tabs = page.find_tables()  # locate tables on page
    if len(tabs.tables) == []:  # no tables found?
        break  # stop
    tab = tabs[0]  # assume fragment to be 1st table

    # "tables" should contain DataFrames, not objects from different pages,
    # which do no longer exist.
    tables.append(tab.to_pandas())  # append this DataFrame


# Everything as expected until here
tables_2 = []
for page in doc_2:  # iterate over the pages
    tabs = page.find_tables()  # locate tables on page
    if len(tabs.tables) == []:  # no tables found?
        break  # stop
    tab = tabs[0]  # assume fragment to be 1st table
    tables_2.append(tab)  # append this DataFrame

# This returns text from the input1.pdf, not national-capitals.pdf as intended
df = pd.concat([tab for tab in tables])  # now "tables" contains DataFrames already
```

We will add logic that prevents wrong usage as you provoked it.
Thanks for submitting this!

issue.title: RuntimeError: exception stack overflow! when reading pages

labels.name: not a bug
labels.description: not a bug / user error / unable to reproduce

issue.body:
## Describtion of the bug
A stack overflow appear when I try to convert all the pages of the PDF to text.

```
File ".local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/fitz/utils.py", line 825, in get_text
    tp = page.get_textpage(clip=clip, flags=flags)
File ".local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/fitz/fitz.py", line 6017, in get_textpage
    textpage = self._get_textpage(clip, flags=flags, matrix=matrix)
File ".local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/fitz/fitz.py", line 6003, in _get_textpage
    val = _fitz.Page__get_textpage(self, clip, flags, matrix)
RuntimeError: exception stack overflow!
```

## To Reproduce

```
import io
import requests
import fitz

pdf_link = 'https://arxiv.org/pdf/2107.10846.pdf'
request = requests.get(pdf_link, timeout=20)
filestream = io.BytesIO(request.content)

with fitz.open(stream=filestream, filetype="pdf") as doc: 
    pages = [page.get_text() for page in doc]
```

 - Python 3.10.12 64bits

comment.body:
Both PDF examples have 1 damaged page. Try Adobe Acrobat to confirm.
There is no way around this but wrapping your text extraction in a try/except construct.
